channel.title: Posts on Accelerator project journal
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Accelerator project journal

item.title: Building a tool to benchmark search: Results and lessons learnt
item.description: This is the second in a series of blog posts about what I worked on for my data science accelerator project at GDS. It follows part 1: motivation. What I built During the 11? 12? days of the programme, I built a data pipeline that fitted a simplified dynamic bayesian network model to my data about search clicks. As I alluded to in the previous post, this model allows me to estimate the probability of a document being relevant to users who entered a certain search term.

item.title: Building a tool to benchmark search: Motivation
item.description: This is the first in a series of blog posts about what I worked on for my data science accelerator project at GDS. Recap: why did I propose this project? GOV.UK is all about joining up goverment services and information so users can find stuff and understand goverment. This is hard because the government is not a single entity - it’s a bunch of separate departments and agencies with different priorties, responsibilities and ways of working.

item.title: Wrapping up the project
item.description: Last week was the final week of the project, so this is where I wrap up. I had intended to blog all the way through the project, but I gave up somewhere in the middle after hitting some roadblocks and losing motivation. I was quite busy with other things at the time so I wanted to keep more of my evenings and weekends free. I didn’t stop writing things down, but I stuck to notetaking instead of blogging.

item.title: Half way through - what's left to do
item.description: I have 6 or 7 weeks left. Which is basically 6 or 7 days + however much of my own time I can spend on it. There’s a lot left to do. I think there are broadly 5 things for me to focus on, but I don’t think I’ll be able to achieve everything. 1. Get more data in Add in data from the last week Tokenize and stem queries so similar ones can be grouped together Investigate whether it makes sense to group queries with the same result sets 2.

item.title: Half way through - what I've done so far
item.description: We are half way through the accelerator program and Thursday morning I had a half day meeting and retrospective with the other accelerants. It was really good to have a chance to talk to everyone, but I’m finding the limited time very stressful. I’m not sure yet whether the program is going to be 11 or 12 weeks, because we started a week late but there is a venue booking for presentations at the end which hasn’t been changed yet.

item.title: Predicting search result relevance with a click model
item.description: For my project I want to use search logs to model user behaviour on GOV.UK search. The approach I want to follow is based on a paper titled A Dynamic Bayesian Network Click Model for Web Search Ranking (Chapelle and Zhang 2009) Overview of the paper The Dynamic Bayesian Network model is one of many click models for modelling search behaviour in terms of random variables. Given a search engine result page, a click model should be able to predict the probability that a user will click on any of the links on the page.

item.title: Week 4 update
item.description: I postponed my project day on week 4, and I’m going to make up the time next week instead. This week I joined a new team at work, and I also had some data issues to work out, so I thought I’d make better use of my time this way. I can hopefully work on it uninterrupted on Thursday and Friday. So this week I’ve just been working on the project when I’ve had free time, but I’ve written code to extract the data I need and I’ve also loaded it into a postgres database so it’s easier for me to query.

item.title: Data problems
item.description: This week was really unproductive. I hit some roadblocks with the data so I didn’t accomplish what I set out to do on Thursday. I’m finding this really stressful at the moment as I’m really worried that I won’t be able to get the data I need to actually do the project I proposed. ðŸ˜ž What I planned to do Thursday My aim for this weak was to work out how to use Google BigQuery to fetch the data I need instead of the google Analytics API, because:

item.title: Getting some data
item.description: This week my main goal was to get some data and explore it. I spent most of it figuring out how the Google Analytics API works. I found this quite daunting at first because the “getting started” documentation doesn’t link to a proper reference, and I didn’t have a good understanding of the concepts behind google analytics. But I found a couple of useful resources: The dimensions and metrics explorer gave me most of the information I needed to query the API.

item.title: How does GOV.UK search work at the moment?
item.description: The search functionality on GOV.UK is built using an open source search engine, Elasticsearch. In this post I’ll explain how GOV.UK search uses elasticsearch to generate search results, and some of the problems with it. Indexing Whenever a new document is published, it automatically gets added to a search index. When you index a document, elasticsearch analyses the document’s text, which involves lowercasing, stripping out diacretics, breaking it into tokens, stemming words, substituting synonyms etc.

item.title: About this project
item.description: Hi! Over the next 3 months I’m going to be spending 1 day a week working on a project as part of the government data science accelerator programme. I’m encouraged to keep a journal and I thought a blog would be a good way to do it. Background I currently work as a software developer on GOV.UK, the website used by people in the UK to access government services and information online.
